text: 6 Minute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBCLearningEnglish. I'm Neil.
And I’m Georgie.
speaker: Georgie

text: So Georgie, I'd like to know if you have any brothers or sisters and if you get on well with them.
Yes, I do. I have a sister and we get on very well.
We didn't use to, but now that we're adults, we get on well.
Well, in this programme we'll be discussing one of the closest relationships there is,
the connection between sisters.
We'll hear from three Irish sisters, reuniting on a radio show.
And from a psychotherapist on some stereotypes about sisterhood.
Plus, we'll be learning some useful new vocabulary too.
And remember, if you want to read along while you listen,
you can find the script for this programme on our website, BBCLearningEnglish.com.
Yeah, great idea.
Now, whether you have one or not, our history and culture is full of sisters
from the fairy tale of Cinderella and her ugly sisters to tennis players,
Venus and Serena Williams.
And currently, two sisters, Ellie and Rachel Reeves,
are senior ministers in the British government.
So Neil, my question for you is this.
What is Rachel Reeves' government job?
a)    Home Secretary?
speaker: Georgie

text: b)    Foreign Secretary? or
speaker: Georgie

text: c)    Chancellor of the Exchequer?
speaker: Georgie

text: Well I think the answer is c) the Chancellor of the Exchequer, which is the name of the finance minister in the UK.
speaker: Neil

text: which is the name for the finance minister in the UK.
OK, Neil, we'll find out if that's the correct answer later in the programme.
speaker: Georgie

text: Newlamma Governe, the presenter of BBC Radio 4's Woman's Hour, has two sisters.
They both live in Ireland so they're joining me on a video call. Hello Eileen. Hello Vera. Welcome to Woman’s Hour.
speaker: Nuala McGovern

text: Hello, Eileen. Hello, Vera. Welcome to Woman's Hour.
Hello. Hello.
Hi.
Nula was born in Dublin and moved to New York, then London, to work as a journalist,
while her two sisters stayed in Ireland.
Here she introduces her older sister, Vera and younger sister, Eileen,
for a BBC Radio 4 Woman's Hour special about sisterhood.
Nula was a little worried what her sisters would say about her on the radio,
so let's listen in and find out.
Eileen, what would you say if you were to describe our relationship as sisters?
speaker: Nuala McGovern

text: Very connected, I think, and we do get on very well which I'm proud to say.
speaker: get on

text: Yes, I'm just right.
Here, I'm going to put you on the spot, Vera.
Yes, exactly. I’m going to put you on the spot, Vera. What word would you use to describe me as a sister?
speaker: put you on the spot

text: I couldn't give you words, but you definitely marched to your own drum.
What would that word be?
Independent?
speaker: Nuala McGovern

text: Independent?
speaker: Eileen

text: You liked to control the situation.
Eileen thinks she gets on with her sisters.
Eileen thinks she gets on with her sisters. To get on with someone means to like them and have a good relationship with them.
speaker: gets onget on

text: Nula puts her older sister on the spot by asking Vera to describe her in one word.
When you put someone on the spot, you make them answer a difficult question then and there,
sometimes making them embarrassed or uncomfortable.
But Nula didn't need to worry what her sisters would say.
Vera simply said that Nula marches to her own drum.
She does things in her own way, which may be different from how other people do things.
It seems Vera, Nula and Eileen have remained close friends as they've grown up,
but the relationship between older, middle, and younger sisters isn't always so harmonious.
Let's listen to BBC Radio 4's Women's Hour special programme
as Nula is joined by psychotherapist Jennifer Glethill.
Thank you very much to Eileen and Vera.
What a treat to have a chat with my sisters about sisters.
I want to bring in Jennifer here who's listening to it all.
Some of the stereotypes around siblings that the elder sister is bossy,
the middle sister is a peacemaker and the little sister is spoiled,
that is not applying to our family.
But I'm wondering, is there any substance about or why does that even get bandied around?
We love giving people labels, don't we?
We like to put people into categories and then we can make sense of behaviours.
But actually, since then, scientists find no proof of being these rebels in the families.
Nula discusses stereotypes about siblings, a word that means either brother or sister.
One stereotype is that the older sister is usually bossy.
She enjoys telling people what to do.
Another stereotype is that the younger sister is spoiled.
If you describe a child as spoiled,
you mean they are allowed to do anything they want,
often with the result that they behave badly.
What do you think about these stereotypes, Georgie? Are they true for you and your sister?
speaker: Neil

text: Are they true for you and your sister?
I'm not sure I agree with these stereotypes because the older sister is meant to be bossy, but my younger sister is the bossy one. I don’t think I’m bossy at all.
speaker: Georgie

text: but my younger sister is the bossy one.
I don't think I'm bossy at all.
Well, that's interesting.
Jennifer did say that there's no scientific proof.
Anyway, it's time now to find out the answer to your question, Georgie.
Yes, and my question was, what is Rachel Reeves' government job?
And you guessed she was the chancellor of the ex-checker,
which was the correct answer.
Well done, Neil.
Hooray!
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned in this program.
Starting with the phrasal verb, get on with someone,
meaning to have a good relationship with them.
If you put someone on the spot, you cause them embarrassment by forcing them to answer a difficult question at that very moment.
speaker: someone on the spot

text: answer a difficult question at that very moment.
If you march to your own drum, you do things in your own unique way, regardless of how other people do them.
speaker: march to your own drum

text: regardless of how other people do them.
A sibling can mean either a brother or sister.
speaker: sibling

text: People who are bossy enjoy telling other people what to do.
speaker: bossy

text: And finally, a spoiled child is allowed to do whatever they want,
becoming badly behaved as a result.
Once again, our six minutes are up, but remember to head over to BBCLearningEnglish.com,
where you can find loads more fun and helpful resources,
including a worksheet and quiz for this program.
Bye for now!
speaker: Georgie

text: Goodbye!
speaker: Neil
